title: about
text: just a kid running around pretending to be a fake-adult. i like to read and listen to music and people watch and play video games and hang out with my friends in the middle of the street late at night and exercise and learn new things. i unabashedly call my mom or dad most everyday and have a collection of mini things on my windowsill and am deadly afraid of being bored and alone (both separately and at once). this is just where i dump things to feel like i am giving my brain a shower, or get the tv static out of my joints and brain.

title: A Court of Thorns and Roses / Sarah J. Maas
text:
finished 6/4/23
this book was one i had resisted reading for a long time because it’s so controversial and didn’t really seem like something up my alley. i really did not like feyre (also how tf do you say that name) - she just made everything worse and generally was just a whiner. there were definitely some parts that were good plot-wise and the villain was fantastic, but overall i skimmed this one.

title: The Story of the Human Body / Daniel E. Lieberman
text:
finished 12/7/23
had to think about this one for a minute. i loved all of this book except for the last 3 chapters- the other chapters are super informative and fascinating and full of cool facts about our bodies. i was introduced to so many new ideas (mismatch diseases, dysevolution etc) that were so interesting, and definitely will have me thinking differently about my body when it is sick or injured. that said, the last 3 or so chapters bugged me because he begins to address solutions to some of the problems created by mismatch between our bodies and environments, but most, if not all, of his solutions come from a very privileged position. many of the suggested solutions base themselves on the assumption that all people have access and/or the means to access things such as fresh fruits and veggies, probiotics, jobs that require the ‘right’ amount of stress or activity etc. the mismatches between our bodies and modern environment affect all people, and so solutions need to cater to people from all walks of life. i don’t know the answers either, but the ones in the book definitely aren’t for everyone.

title: Unbroken / Laura Hillenbrand
text:
finished 10/2/24
this story is told so matter of factly, and the things that happen to Louie seem so unreal, that it is hard to remember at times that it’s a true story and not some ridiculous fiction. really makes you think about what it means to be internally strong and resilient, and gave me a great admiration for survivors of POW camps- the dehumanization is abhorrent. real good read, but a hard one to swallow.

title: Isaac and the Egg / Bobby Palmer
text:
finished 7/1/23
this one was so so good. i picked it up in scotland because it was buy one get one half off and i needed the paperback of tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow so i just grabbed it because of the title. it’s really sad (about a husband grieving the death of his wife) but so brilliantly written. also the egg is hilarious.

title: The Girl Who Played with Fire / Stieg Larsson
text:
finished 5/2/23
loved it- it had crime, murder, pro boxers and computer hacking. what more could you ask for?

title: The Poppy War / R.F. Kuang
text:
finished 4/30/25
really dark but written super well. rin becomes kind of irritating, and is clearly lost in her own opportunity for power. will be interesting to see how the rest of the story pans out in the next books (if i get to them lol)

title: The Memoirs of Stockholm Sven / Nathaniel Ian Miller
text:
finished 5/23/24 \ I have never really read a story like this. The setting and environment was so unique, and in an area i had never even heard of, which was so fascinating to learn about. also i just liked that the story wasn’t about one romantic relationship, or someone’s life’s mission, but was more about a life lived learning about companionship and isolation and how to be a person. just a really singular and unique story- really loved it.
also should i go on the Arctic Circle Expeditionary Program?? (https://thearcticcircle.org/)

title: What the Fireflies Knew / Kai Harris
text:
finished 1/30/23
A book about a girl and her sister and their mother who leaves them out of love with her father who she is learning to forgive. I liked this one until the eleven year old narrator was sexually assaulted behind a dumpster, which was then used as an experience that, once revealed, brought her closer to her sister, who had been physically abused by their now deceased father. However, neither of these traumatic events were brought to any type of resolution, and then the book just kind of ended, and we should be telling girls every goddamned day that they should not have to live with those things, carrying those heavy weights.

title: Dune Messiah / Frank Herbert
text:
finished 5/3/24
this was tricky to get into because i had forgotten a lot of what happened in Dune, and was getting confused between the movies and the book. also i was confused because it starts after the 12 year jihad, which Paul literally spent all of the first book talking about preventing, and then this book started and was like “ok the jihad happened and billions of people died and Paul is Emperor ok go.” but overall i really liked it- i liked that Paul becomes more of a villain and the dynamic of group that is trying to kill him (they all kind of hate each other which was pretty funny even though the dictatorship wins in the end and they are all killed) and the plot was really enticing. was skeptical at first because the jihad was just kind of glossed over within the first couple chapters (it is revisited more in the rest of the book) and it seemed like a big thing to skip, but i can see why it wasn’t super relevant to include all the gory details after reading the whole book. good read!

title: The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down / Anne Fadiman
text:
finished 2/25/23
What would you do? The parents love their daughter unconditionally the only way they know how, and the doctors want to heal her unrelentlessly the only way they know how. The second to last chapter is called “The Life or the Soul” and that pretty much sums it up. How do you fix a problem created by the fact that no one party is correct- a war of moralities and differences of opinion in which there is no true positive? I think probably the first step is to listen to each other.

title: Reproduction / Ian Williams
text:
finished 4/24/23
all of the men were assholes in this book. there was a thing one of the characters brought up which was “contributing to the GDP of the house” and it was pretty funny because he was 36, in a serious amount of debt and living in his mom’s basement. you can tell a poet wrote this book. i like the switchups of narrative style, and there were a lot of plot points that came by surprise which was cool. the last section was a slog to get through, just because of the writing style, but damn did it make me think about how i consider families and love as intertwined concepts, and maybe they aren’t always in a matrix? i dunno

title: Before the coffee gets cold / Toshikazu Kawaguchi
text:
finished 1/17/24
aunt jody got me this one for christmas this year, and it was a really great read! it’s almost told in 4 different mini stories, but they all have the same base characters, which carries a nice continuity through the stories. mostly it’s just about people and their grief and how they choose to heal from it in very human ways. i wish i could read japanese, because i’m sure reading it without the barrier of translation is beautiful.

title: Bel Canto / Ann Patchett
text:
finished 2/5/23
This book was so wonderfully written, but the ending was such a cop out. If you read it, skip the epilogue and enjoy the singing and the people as they stand in the grass under the sun and in love with those they should hate.

title: Becoming / Michelle Obama
text:
finished 1/16/23
Made me and my icy heart cry like a baby. A realistic story about a person who refuses to be a shadow, and is endlessly driven to use her platform for action in a society that resists with all its strength. Also, the pictures are so cute.

title: Killers of the Flower Moon / David Grann
text: finished 3/17/24 - this entire story is so fucked - really well researched and the story was told very precisely and with the right attitude about the whole thing - seriously what the fuck

title: Harry Potter / J.K. Rowling
text:
been re-reading the harry potter series in an attempt to get out of my reading slump. just going to plop all of the reviews on one page here because seven hp pages seemed excessive.
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone
so much fun- I really forgot how enjoyable these are to read.
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
snake
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
buckbeak + hagrid = <3
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
hermione’s dress is blue!! riot.
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
god harry is such a little whiner in this one it’s unbearable.

title: The Princess Bride / William Goldman
text: finished 3/5/24 - such a fun and silly book - great escapism - much funnier than i anticipated - “my name is inigo montoya. you killed my father. prepare to die.”

title: Cloud Atlas / David Mitchell
text: finished 4/20/23 already want to re-read this one. the characters are so individualized, which is super impressive given that there are 6 different storylines in significantly different settings, that somehow manage to be woven together in this beautiful and elegant way. can’t begin to understand how you think of or write something this complex, but this book is phenomenal nonetheless.

title: Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil / John Berendt
text: finished 1/29/24 i started reading this book fully thinking that it was fiction, and was subsequently really shocked when i looked it up on storygraph and figured out that it was in fact non-fiction. i’m not sure i have ever read a non-fiction book quite like this one- there is so much dialogue that it reads really easily, and it makes the characters so much more lively. the writing and terminology is definitely dated, but the story is so exciting and really keeps you reeled in. i can’t believe jim williams was tried 4 times, found guilty the first 3 times, and then acquitted at the last trial! crazy shit. anyways, really liked this one, would recommend to anyone who just wants a story about weird whacky humans living in a bubble where a murder happens.

title: Somewhere Beyond the Sea / T.J. Klune
text: finished 9/16/24 \ (sequel to The House in the Cerulean Sea) sorry this book was sickeningly good. i love every character (except the bad ones), they are all so funny and endearing and lifelike and even though it was sappy at times god it was so good.

title: Say Nothing / Patrick Radden Keefe
text:
finished 3/12/23
a book has never made me feel so un-informed (is that a word?). the Troubles were, and continue to be, such a tragedy for all of Ireland, and the people who were directly affected will carry it forever. there was no sugarcoating of anything, or pretending it wasn’t as bad as it was. i am really interested to see what becomes of the Belfast Project at Boston College - it was such a fascinating idea that ended up going completely awry. anyways, this piece of history is a huge can of worms and i think i’ve got a lot more reading to do about it but this book is phenomenally done.

title: Little Bee / Chris Cleave
text:
finished 5/23/23
found this book on the free table in willamette and that was super exciting. about a nigerian refugee in the UK, so gorgeously written but all of them die in devastating ways and batman can’t save anyone.

title: A Thousand Acres / Jane Smiley
text:
finished 3/18/23
contrary to what i assumed based on the author’s last name, this is not a happy book. i do understand why it won a pulitzer though- the writing is stunning and the characters (sans narrator) are so grossly horrible to each other in these intensely personal and pointed ways, which just proves the strength of smiley’s writing. makes me appreciate my own sisters and that i haven’t ever been mad enough to construct a premeditated murder plot based off of sausages in a jar.

title: The Song of the Cell / Siddhartha Mukherjee
text:
finished 1/14/24
phenomenal. the blend of his personal stories and experiences with hardcore science, as well as the lyrical language surrounding all of the fascinating history around the discovery of the different parts of the cell is brilliant. i was just as amazed as i was reading The Gene because he is able to craft these intricate and complex scientific histories into dramatic and understandable and riveting stories. loved it.

title: Educated / Tara Westover
text:
finished 10/17/24
a really powerful read about family and growth and the importance of your own knowledge. parts were really hard to read, but i have so much respect for the author and her conviction in herself.

title: Foundryside / Robert Jackson Bennett
text:
finished 11/5/24
this was literally about a talking key named clef. kind of got better at the end? pretty dumb, but at least the magic portion was creative.

title: The God of Small Things / Arundhati Roy
text:
finished 4/6/24
hey what? to be fair (to be fairrrrr) i did pick this up from goodwill without reading the blurb or reading anything about it online. here are my thoughts in bullet point format - wtf - was not prepped for the sexual assault of a minor in the third chapter - kind of hard to track the plot sometimes because the language is languishing and exploratory and feels meandering - but also the language is beautiful? “the god of small things” god what a beautiful phrase - loved the unconventional capitalized phrases - devastating and upsetting - good i think - need to think more about it - political pieces are very interesting - realized I know next to nothing about the politcal plane of India in the late 60s post British liberation

title: The Healing of America / T. R. Reid
text:
finished 1/24/23
Makes you do some big thinking about the selfishness of US government. I really liked Reid’s approach of first researching and getting first hand experience with health care systems of other nations that are comparable to the US in other metrics, and then broaching the topic of actually reforming our health care system- I thought it was well thought out and researched, and provided realistic suggestions for action. Also, the dedication really sticks it to people who argue that we shouldn’t take inspiration from other countries, which is pretty fun.

No matching items

title: A Court of Mist and Fury / Sarah J. Maas
text:
finished 6/10/23
yeah this was also pretty dumb, i skimmed most of it.

title: Migrations / Charlotte McConaghy
text:
finished 4/26/25
oh i cried like a little baby. GORGEOUS writing. this is not a book about birds, but a book about mothers and daughters and wandering until you get home and loving someone where they are at.

title: Liar and Spy / Rebecca Stead
text:
finished 6/4/23
definitely have read this before and knew it was good, but couldn’t remember why. if you lie to make friends, is it worth it?

title: Never Let Me Go / Kazuo Ishiguro
text:
finished 7/20/23
i was really excited about this one because i have been meaning to read Kazuo Ishiguro’s stuff for awhile. this book really caught me off guard- the writing is really casual and then just throws in details like that the kids are being raised to donate their organs or that they are cloned from other people. overall i really liked it!

title: Our Hideous Progeny / C. E. McGill
text:
finished 2/24/24
this was a really interesting one- i don’t think it’s one i ever would have picked out for myself, but mama got it for me for christmas and the cover art is wicked cool (but don’t judge a book by it’s cover) so i gave it a shot. it’s inspired by frankenstein and is about a woman and her idiot husband and the woman discovers her great-uncle’s research where he made a man come alive. mary and her dummy husband are both geologists and decide to try this on a plesiosaurus because why not and that’s the story. but also it’s about mary and her miscarriage and being a woman in the mid 19th century and having no autonomy or voice in a conversation and also it’s queer and mary has a thing for her stupid husband’s sister and it’s about grief and letting go of the things you love or once loved. i never watched that movie the way of water but based on the trailers i kind of imagined the Creature like the thing from that movie. i don’t know i really liked it because it didn’t try too hard to be something it wasn’t.

title: The Perfect Storm / Sebastian Junger
text:
finished 4/4/24
for the sake of honesty, i have read this before, but evidently had forgotten because i didn’t remember that until the third chapter or so. anyways, amazing journalism, it’s a tragic story but the book is so well researched and the story is told very well. I do wish that I had some type of background that had given me boat and ocean and fishing knowledge, because I think I would have understood a ton more, but that’s also partially on me because I didn’t really do a lot (any) looking into terms that were confusing and just sort of relied on context clues to understand what was going on. but anyways, the ocean is insane and I am definitely not destined to be a fisherman on a swordfish boat.

title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest / Stieg Larsson
text:
finished 6/30/23
Just as good as the other two- this one definitely has more characters and storylines to keep track of, but it was still awesome. lots of spying and crime and intrigue, very fun.

title: Breathing Lessons / Anne Tyler
text:
finished 6/30/23
this one was pretty slow, but i really liked it. tells the story of maggie and ira as they go on a road trip to go to an old friend’s funeral. lots of talk about family, and how much work a marriage is, and how to love the ones we love when they make decisions we wouldn’t make ourselves.

title: Let the Great World Spin / Colum McCann
text:
finished 10/26/24
ok this was a really cool read- i love books where all the characters end up being connected in some way, and this was exactly that. the writing style was really unique and lyrical, and i loved the intimacy/closeness of the story and the characters despite being in the huge setting of nyc. i don’t know, i like reading about people. sometimes it’s easier to read about them than talk to them.

title: Bridge of Clay / Marcus Zusak
text:
finished 11/8/23
it’s lyrical and masterful, a lot like singing or riding a horse or telling a story, there’s a rhythm to it, it ebbs and flows. cried through the last 50 pages, made me feel boneless. god i love my family. the writing can make the story a bit confusing to follow, but it’s tragic and brilliant anyways. reminded me of this music: - gregory alan isakov (artist) - the bride and the bachelor / magnolian - girl in calico live with skylightcity string quartet / tow’rs

title: Demon Copperhead / Barbara Kingsolver
text:
finished 4/2/23
This was really damn good. It was interesting reading kingsolver writing a male narrator because so far I’ve only read ones of hers that are narrated by women. The writing style is stunning, because she figured out a way to give an accurate voice to this uneducated, wicked smart kid that doesn’t dumb him down or make him unrelatable. Demon’s blunt self-awareness of his self destruction at the end is so heartbreaking, but I liked the ending I think. The biggest part that resonated with me was the whole thing about the city vs. the green grass and always wanting to be back with who and where you came from and not liking the dead quiet that exists without cicadas or the rain or birds. I’m a little homesick.

title: The House in the Cerulean Sea / TJ Klune
text:
finished (third reread) 2/11/23
This stupid book. 10 out of 5.

title: The Sweet Hereafter / Russell Banks
text:
finished 11/26/23
i really liked the writing style of this book - i am always impressed when authors are able to create such unique and individualized voices for different characters to the point that you can tell who is narrating without the author having to explicitly state whose point of view the story is currently being told from. the story is really tragic, and i wanted resolution at the end for Nichole and for her dad to go to prison for a long long time. but i guess the point is that everyone grieves their own tragedies differently, but it made me sad that dolores felt so much relief at being blamed for the accident and that she lost her community (except for abbott). overall i really liked it, but it made me sad too.

title: King Zeno / Nathaniel Rich
text:
finished 3/28/24 this was a weird one. at first it was a slow-burn murder and then it sped up and got pretty fast paced and really exciting which was a big switch up. i really liked how all of the characters eventually intertwined, but it was a little bit confusing to pick up the plot at the beginning because the language could be pretty languorous and abstract, which isn’t bad but was a little tricky because of the omniscient narrator situation. also the cover art is so sick.
other random thoughts I had while reading this book that i wrote down on a receipt: - writing matches tone of scenes - words and sentences thick like molasses - have to reread to understand some parts because a lot goes over my head

title: The Complete Maus / Art Spiegelman
text:
finished 2/25/24
jesus christ this was devastating and beautifully written and illustrated. i really love non-fiction graphic novels because they are able to portray so much emotion, and this was no different. the use of animals to make differences between people so blatant was brilliant. i also really liked how spiegelman incorporated the struggles of his relationship with his dad while also attempting to understand what he endured through the holocaust. so so intelligent and well-done.

title: Babel: An Arcane History / R. F. Kuang
text:
finished 2/20/24
this was brilliant. the characters are so dense and real and the story is intriguing and full of mystery and adventure and surprises and i loved it. i especially loved how love was portrayed- the themes of navigating platonic love when the other person has huge differences of opinion or just generally when rifts appear in a friendship are so well done. also, the discussions of colonialism and how not to be blind in your privilege are well expanded and really well navigated. definitely the second half of the book got way more adventurous and exciting than i thought it would, just based on the slower pace of the beginning, but it made sense with the building presence of the Hermes Society and things just finally becoming unavoidable. overall extraordinary.

title: Tom Lake / Ann Patchett
text:
finished 2/29/24
i don’t often read fiction books that make me feel as understood or perceived as this book did. it’s about three daughters listening to their mom’s story of a summer romance with a famous actor years ago. they are all at home because of the pandemic, and having to find ways to entertain themselves. it’s told from the mom’s perspective, and she talks about her daughters and how to give them pieces of her past self and also keep some for herself and the differences between her daughters and none of this makes a lot of sense but this book was so wonderful and it just made me feel heard.

title: The Bean Trees / Barbara Kingsolver
text:
finished 10/24/23
mothers and daughters and the love between them. another brilliant one from barbara kingsolver.

title: American Gods / Neil Gaiman
text:
finished 12/28/23
definitely adding this one to my re-read list. the story is so complex, and it’s really impressive how given that, the story is still clear and easy to understand. i love the characters because even though they are supposed to be gods, they are really closer to real people. they have flaws and and can die and want to be loved. i want to read the comic because i wonder how the visuals in my head compare to how Gaiman envisioned them. i don’t know, i really liked this one.

title: Cloud Cuckoo Land / Anthony Doerr
text:
finished 7/16/23
i really liked this one- mama said she didn’t like it so much because there wasn’t really a moral or something obvious to get out of it, which i think is why i really liked it. it was just a story about people telling stories, and there wasn’t any greater meaning that was being forced down my throat. also i love the name and the story cloud cuckoo land is really pretty funny. omeir’s oxen moonlight and tree broke my heart.

title: The Dictionary of Lost Words
text: finished 1/31/24 i really liked this one! the language was so beautiful, and the feminist themes were really well expounded upon. the extreme challenges of being a working woman in the late 19th - early 20th century were presented just subtly enough to get the point across without having to be blatant about the themes she was addressing. i thought the plot was beautiful, and it was really interesting to learn about the making of the first dictionary also.

title: Skippy Dies / Paul Murray
text:
finished 7/7/23
this one was a long one (>600 pgs), but very glad i read it. super funny and addresses the lives of teenagers and kids in a really honest way. the language the author uses to write the dialogue of the boys is so genuine and hilarious and the characters are so well developed. gets pretty sad at the end (spoiler: skippy does die) but it’s handled with grace and truth. fantastic read.

title: The Boys in the Boat / Daniel James Brown
text: finished 4/23/24 - really want to watch the movie now - a little bit sappy, but a wicked story overall - super interesting to learn more about the 1936 Olympics under Hitler, and all of the insane propaganda and lying that was going on during the games - loved that the crew continued to get together to row on the 10 year anniversaries of their win

title: Watchmen / Alan Moore, Dave Gibbons
text:
finished 1/21/24
love a good graphic novel- this one is dark and ominous and made me do a lot of thinking about how the world functions when at war. i really liked the character development, which i think was also influenced by this book being a graphic novel, because you can visually see how the author envisioned the characters, rather than just by description. the art was fantastic as well, because it was also dark and dramatic and matched with the mood of the story. i also liked how the major tragedy at the end did end up happening, and the authors didn’t shy away from the pseudo-superheroes not saving the day. at the end of the day, they were just weirdo normal-ish people who just decided to become superheroes based on their elevated egos and anxieties about the state of the world. rorschach was a super interesting character, because his superhero identity started out well intentioned, but then devolved into this villanous character who acted under the pretense of ridding society of evils, but did a lot of evil himself. really well done.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird / Harper Lee
text: finished (again) 5/28/23 this book is so important to me.

title: Safe Area Goražde / Joe Sacco
text:
finished 5/15/23
learned a ton from this book about the war in Bosnia and all of the horrifying things that happened during it. the art and writing style is so well done, and doesn’t romanticize any of the tragedies, but rather humanizes it all.

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow / Gabrielle Zevin
text:
finished 2/5/23
This is a story about some people with the normal type of messed up lives. The characters are well formed and the narration of their inner thoughts is woven together so seamlessly that the book flows through their timeline in such a way that you don’t realize the book is over until it is and you wish it wasn’t.
finished again 7/9/23
i got my hands on a paperback copy of this one in scotland and then had to read it again- just as good as the first time. i loved being able to read portions of the beginning knowing how things were going to pan out because i just got so much more out of it. lovely and brilliant

title: bucket
text: here’s a bunch of stuff that is floating around in the bucket of my brain

2025 book stats

genre stats


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# updated 5-12-25
fiction = 7
nonfiction = 3

## make pie chart
labels = ['fiction', 'non-fiction']
num = [fiction, nonfiction]
colors = ['#56505d', '#df3a26']

plt.pie(num, labels=labels, colors=colors, autopct='%1.0f%%')
plt.show()





% fiction and non-fiction reads this year






books by month


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px


months = ['jan 25', 'feb 25', 'mar 25', 'apr 25', 'may 25']
counts = [1, 2, 1, 5, 1]

d = {'month': months, 'books': counts}


df = pd.DataFrame(data=d)


# fig, ax = plt.subplots()
# ax.plot(months, counts, '#df3a26', **{'marker': 'o'})
# ax.set_xlabel('month')
# ax.set_ylabel('# books read')
# plt.show()

fig = px.line(df, x="month", y="books", title='books read by month', markers=True)
fig.show()

all time stats
all time meaning the whole time i have been tracking this nerd shit ### all time books by month


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px


months = ['jan 24', 'feb 24', 'mar 24', 'apr 24', 'may 24', 'jun 24', 'jul 24', 'aug 24', 'sep 24', 'oct 24', 'nov 24', 'dec 24', 'jan 25', 'feb 25', 'mar 25', 'apr 25', 'may 25']
counts = [5, 4, 3, 3, 2, 1, 0, 0, 1, 3, 1, 3, 1, 2, 1, 5, 1]

d = {'month': months, 'books': counts}


df = pd.DataFrame(data=d)


# fig, ax = plt.subplots()
# ax.plot(months, counts, '#df3a26', **{'marker': 'o'})
# ax.set_xlabel('month')
# ax.set_ylabel('# books read')
# plt.show()

fig = px.line(df, x="month", y="books", title='books read by month', markers=True)
fig.show()
